name: (2E)-3-oxo-3-thiophen-2-yl-2-{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}propanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1250

name: (2E)-3-oxo-3-thiophen-2-yl-2-{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}propanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1250
Reason: To predict the melting point for the target compound (2E)-3-oxo-3-thiophen-2-yl-2-{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}propanenitrile, we must consider the effects of the various functional groups and structural characteristics compared to a known basic structure such as benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Firstly, thiophene is similar to benzene but due to sulfur it adds around +20°C to the melting point. The carbonyl group (C=O) typically raises the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds and its polarity, adding another +40°C. The hydrazone part (N-N=C) adds rigidity and opportunities for hydrogen bonding, increasing by roughly +20°C. The nitrile group (C#N) introduces dipole-dipole interactions and can add around +25°C. The trifluoromethyl group (-CF3) is highly electronegative, significantly increasing melting point by around +50°C due to strong dipole moments and possible intermolecular interactions. Adding these adjustments together gives us an estimated increase of 155°C to the base structure of benzene.

name: (2E)-3-oxo-3-thiophen-2-yl-2-{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}propanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1250
Reason: To predict the melting point of the target compound (2E)-3-oxo-3-thiophen-2-yl-2-{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}propanenitrile, the impacts of various functional groups must be evaluated based on a basic structure. Starting with benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C, the addition of a thiophene ring is expected to increase the melting point due to the heavier sulfur atom and slight aromatic character, contributing approximately +30°C. A carbonyl group typically adds polarity and potential for H-bonding, increasing the melting point by about +40°C. The hydrazone moiety introduces structural rigidity and additional polarity, which could increase the melting point by +20°C. The nitrile group contributes to dipole-dipole interaction, raising the melting point by about +25°C. Finally, the trifluoromethyl group is highly electronegative and could greatly enhance the melting point, adding approximately +50°C due to its strong dipoles and the potential for intermolecular interactions. Summing these individual contributions gives an estimated increase of 165°C over the base structure of benzene.
